scenes.location: ST. RADEGUND, UPPER AUSTRIA, (1940) IN SUDDEN SILEN 1940
characters: FANI, TRYING TO SELL HER PRODUCE 178
REHMAN NIZAR ALI JOE GLEASON SEBASTIAN JONES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single man, raking hay: Franz Jagerstatter, 36 years ol In the distance the steeple of a church and the village w he lives. A few dozen houses, the mountains rising up bey them. * St. Radegund is a small, peaceful village of 500 souls. A its center stands a small square; on one side a Gasthaus, inn; on the other, the rectory. A river flows nearby. The Salzach. Cows graze in the sun. clank of their bells, the lazy swish of their tails. * Returning home from the fields, Franz exchanges greetings with his neighbors. A burn-in reads: “Austria, 1940.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He joins his wife, Franziska, 30. Their daughters, 2 and years old, run out of the barn which stands next to the house. A calf, just born, wobbles to its feet. Franz call Franziska by her nickname, Fani. *

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Girls, help your father! The girl’s names are Rosi and Maridl. Franz picks Maridl and puts her on his shoulders, while Rosi begs to be take the same way. A bell rings in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz dances on the terrace of the inn. Fani laughs and claps. Together they gather plums and apples from the trees in t small orchard. Fani yokes up a cow and sets her to plow. Armed with stones, the children drive crows off the fresh sown fields. Fani milks the cows, makes soap, churns butter. she negotiates with the local miller to have their wheat grou into flour. Rosalia, Franz’s mother, lives with the family and joins out in the fields. She is a widow. Franz’s father died in First World War.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Mother, stay out of the sun. Husband and wife help their neighbors and are helped in t haying, whitewashing their houses, digging out a well. Th rely on each other, a close-knit community.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond his work as a farmer, Franz serves as a sacristan the church. He trims the candles, polishes the pews, ring the bell. He refuses to accept any payment the parishione offer him for his role in arranging baptisms, weddings an funerals. He watches as a painter refurbishes the ceiling with cher and seraphim in transports of ecstasy. He pinches the dead blooms off the roses that grow over t graves of the churchyard outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz helps his mother up a flight of stairs. She is a brooding woman, worn by trouble and care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War scenes from the Eastern Front. German and Russian for plod through the snow, exhausted. Tanks advance by night. Howitzers light up the sky. Stalingrad. Kursk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz and Fani put the children to bed. The girls cry out with delight as their father makes shadows on the ceiling Soon they are asleep, and the house is still.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: These last weeks you're different. What is it? Talk with me. She remembers him in a happy time, riding through the Alp his motorcycle, at a time when he still owned one. His sm as she looked at him. There has been no threat to their happiness. Only a momen few weeks ago, when she heard a faint roar and, looking u barely made out the silhouettes of British planes, bomber in the sky high above, far away. How could the war touch their kingdom, or disturb their peace, when they are so insignificant in the scheme of things, so far from Vienna and Berlin. He touches her belly. She is pregnant now. FANI (CONT’D) We have all we want. All we need. Nothing can change our love. We have our children. Our home. Each other. Nothing can take our happiness away. They pass under a wreath they have set above their door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Yes, my wife. We’ll always have each other.

dialogues.speaker: BABY 9
dialogues.text: A child is born. A girl: Loisi. Her two older sisters loo in amazement. Franz turns to Fani and laughs. Their happi is complete.  10 a. 12 13 14

dialogues.speaker: POSTMAN 10
dialogues.text: The next day they hear the ring of a little bell. The Pos appears on his bicycle with a letter. Franz reads it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: I've been called up. EXT. ORCHARD - RESIE, FANI’S SISTER a1 Fani is with her sister, Resie.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Just for training. A transportation unit.

dialogues.speaker: RESIE
dialogues.text: Are you afraid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz marches in step with a group of draftees.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: After six months we'll be done with this training. Will the war be over? For now I can only be with you in my thoughts. It’s hard when I think of you -- when I remember our home. How is our baby? When I come home, I'll be surprised at how big she is... Have you considered using a horse? I don’t think your team of cows would be offended if you put them in retirement. ROSALIA, FRANZ’S MOTHER 13 Franz's mother, Rosalia, helps Fani load a pig into a car Fani is courteous to her mother-in-law, but Rosalia answe with a certain degree of distrust and suspicion, as if sh imagined Franz had married beneath him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani reaps a field of fresh grass, with Resie and a famil neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother helps me in the fields. It’s no good when we have to rely too much on the neighbors, always asking for help, and thanking them. The Strohofers have been kind. (she thanks the neighbors) The pig almost didn’t fit in the car. Only a boy came for it. It weighed 326 pounds. There was a wedding at the church. (a happy bride outside the church) I've finished tilling the oats. At the start, I had a hard time with the potatoes. It brought me to the point of tears. She puts hay up in the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani feeds the children and puts them to bed.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Rosi is always asking about you. When we're going to bed, she says, “Papa's locked out!” At meals, “Save some for Papa.” If I get up at night, “Is Papa home?” Her sister tells her, “He'll bring sausage!”

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN 16
dialogues.text: The older girls play with Loisi, their new sister.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You know how the children bring me joy. A feeling of good fortune comes over me here, so that tears flow from my eyes, when I think of them, and you, and our reunion. You're doing so much. When I come home, there'll be no more work for me. I’1l become a babysitter! She scolds the girls when they get into mischief, as ofte they do.  17 18 EXT. J FARM a7 Fani washes the cows. She churns milk into butter. She gathers a wagonload of straw. She lays the hay out in windrows to dry.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I have to scold the girls. They argue terribly. They're always demanding my attention. Maridl hits Rosi, who says “You're bad.” Then Maridl says, “I’m good,” and Rosi says, “I’m good, you're bad.” Maridl pulled a leg off of Rosi’s doll and said, “Now the other one comes off, too!” Rosi wanted to go to the doctor to get the leg put back on. (a man in a dark forest) When Sterz is done with his work he goes into the forest and weeps. Toni Strohofer is always hungry. (a hungry man, stealing beets) I could use your help washing the cows. They’re always pleasant in the morning when they eat the leaves of the beets. Mathilde doesn’t wash them before she milks them, so I wash them myself. Mathilde; a lonely girl, knitting as she tends the sheep. FANI (0.S.) (CONT’D) I sold a few pounds of cabbage 3 pfennigs a pound. Frau Huber bought 44, Fani notices a man walking by, looking at Resie. FANI (CONT’D) He's interested in you. Look!

dialogues.speaker: RESIE
dialogues.text: I don’t trust men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz, with other soldiers from his unit. He sees how they defer to the Nazi captain, who lords it them, puffed up with a sense of his importance. They watch newsreels of Nazi victories in the West, show a bedsheet strung from a clothesline.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Much beloved wife! I am grateful for every word you send. Hopefully, winter won't come too soon. The farmers have their beets still in the field. Are you glad we don’t have beets? Franz listens as his comrades roar with delight at the misfortunes of their neighbors. Bewildered French peasant gaze at their German conquerors, ask them for food or fue

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are older now. Loisi has learned to crawl. Franz's mother holds her in leading strings.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Loisi is a little pest. She always wants to be held. Rosi wanted to take your picture to bed with her tonight. You were supposed to sleep beside her. I told her that when father comes home, he will. She answered that father is already home. They gave your photo so many kisses. Rosi recognizes you, but Maridl simply said, “Man.” This morning, I was picking up the piglets. Szailer was there. The calf is now five weeks old. We worked hard this past week, spreading the manure. Toni stott was given 4 months in prison because he spoke out. He opened his mouth too wide. You'll not do the same. Those who speak out lose their leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz speeds down a road on his motorcycle in a military overcoat.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dearly beloved wife! I was delighted to hear from you.  21 22

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hopefully the straw will not run out too early in the spring. You must use it sparingly. Have you greased the scythes and hung them up? Warm greeting from your loving husband, Franz. Many warm greetings to Mother, too, and to the little ones. See you again Franz watches an officer swagger and shout. A cadet, pass by, gives him a Hitler salute. Franz looks away, pretends to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani and Franz’s mother whitewash the house.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Besenbock will be called away. We must send him a goose. (the girls scuffle) Loisi is a dear sparrow. Always trying new things. She doesn’t go far yet. At most a step. She flutters about and falls. Then she is up again. She keeps your mother busy. She wants to be in every scuffle, though she always gets the worst of it. I feel badly for her, and I cannot help her. Her sisters are always the same rascals. Tomorrow I’11 do the cultivating. Hopefully, 1/11 hit no hard spots. I have a fear of such places. Fani works in the fields, spreading manure with a pitchfo Fani greases the scythes and hangs them up in the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While on maneuvers, Franz meets a fellow soldier a few ye younger than himself. His name is Rogowski. There is no pretense about this man. He is kind, generous honest, and endlessly optimistic. He lives in the moment forgetful of the past, with no thought to the future. Rogowski’s face wears the innocent expression of a child, like a child everything he says or does is spontaneous an genuine.  23 24 25 Franz wonders how he lives as he does. Franz's unit is bivouacked by a lake. After early morning calisthenics, they learn their weapons. Franz plunges his bayonet into a straw dummy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It need not be that everything in this world comes about as we want for ourselves. We don’t see the future. It may be a good thing that we don’t. Let’s resolve to begin the new year in confidence and good cheer. I have a few oranges for you. Speak with Schirk. They have the best oats. Whether our oats are also among the best is a good question. Concerning the butchering of the swine, do not wait for me. Fani and Franz’s mother prepare a sow for butchering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Sergeant takes Franz aside.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Lucky man! You've been let go from military service -- to manage your farm! France has surrendered. We'll have peace now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz returns to Radegund. Home! He greets his neighbors he passes through the main square on the way back to his farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani and the children rush out to greet him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: You see? We just had to pray. They celebrate. Franz dances for the children. In the win a light burns past dusk.  26 27 28 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days later, Franz comes across a neighbor in the village square, a farmer named HESSLER. His friends are consoling him. There has been some unexpected event.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Hessler, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: HESSLER
dialogues.text: I've been called up. We thought there would be peace, but this war goes on. I don’t know why. His friends look at each other. Their eyes dart left and right.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Shhh. They pat him on the back. It could happen to anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz questions his friend. Now they are alone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Do you believe in what we’re fighting for?

dialogues.speaker: HESSLER
dialogues.text: A little. No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: We've invaded other countries. Stolen their land. And now we're doing it again. Aren’t they the heroes, who fight against us —- who defend their homes? (no reply) Is something right -- just because the crowd is shouting it? Hessler bows his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passing through the woods, Franz sees a madman in the distance. Dishevelled, his hair and beard grown out; a ma look in his eyes, of fear or dread. It seems the poor fel had not expected anyone to pass this way. He looks at Fra for a moment, then slips off, into the darkness of the tr  29 30 31 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani can see that Franz is holding something back.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: What is it? (after a pause) Toni opened his mouth too wide.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: I wouldn't do anything that would bring you reproach... He looks in on his children. He kisses them as they sleep

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: To have a good husband -- a home -- they’re enough to make you happy... To love and be loved is the greatest happiness on earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz wakes up with a gasp. He lights a candle. Fani look him, startled.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: I had a dream. I saw my father. I asked him what it was like in death. Could he tell me? He shook his head... Then I saw a train -- a wonderful train -- coming through the mountains. The locomotive was powerful -- dark —— it drew the children. They ran to it and weren’t held back. You couldn't see where it was going —— just the trees and fields, flashing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train. A black locomotive. Coal is shovelled into the furnace. The tracks weave in and out. Pistons drive the engine forward: an overwhelming, relentless force.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Then a voice -- the voice said “This train is going into darkness!” I think it was a message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 33 34 12. Franz on his motorcycle, the wind in his hair, the lovely sense of being free of all constraint, rushing on

dialogues.speaker: NEXT MORNING
dialogues.text: The next morning, at breakfast:

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Those other men were like brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighbors debate with Franz.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Who are you? Even the Cardinal ordered us to pray for Hitler -- to ring the bells on his birthday. Fly the swastika from the steeple. You forget.

dialogues.speaker: ECKINGER
dialogues.text: You can’t blame the Cardinal for that. He hoped, by doing it, that the regime would be more tolerant toward the church. But now the priests are sent to concentration camps. Church processions banned. Mass on feast days, even Christmas, prohibited unless the feast falls on Sunday! We don’t have a say. It’s them up the hill that decide our fate. 32 3300 Officials from a fortress near St. Radegund wander throug the street, singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 The fortress, far away. Seat of the military authorities, sits on a high hill, overlooking the valley below. It sta alone in the dusk.

dialogues.speaker: ECKINGER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What do you say, Franz?  35 36 37 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz wanders through the fields, disturbed by the sense a decision may soon be required of him, one that will put happiness of his family at risk and set him at odds with village, which he has loved since he was a boy. Out in the fields, a crucifix stands on a pole, a gabled above it to shelter it from the snow. Uncanny. It stops h in his tracks. The figure on the crucifix looks down at him in silence. Franz turns away, embarrassed. The path wanders on throug the fields of barley. But he cannot leave. He looks up ag takes off his hat. There is no one else in sight. The fie thrum with crickets. Franz takes off his hat, afraid. There are monuments to p everywhere in these mountains. So incongruous. What is it now finds in that face? Franz can tell no one. Especially not those closest to hi He cannot tell his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One afternoon, Franz is cleaning up the church when he co upon a painter, a stranger to these parts.

dialogues.speaker: OHLENDORFF, A PAINTER
dialogues.text: I’m here to touch up the ceiling. Franz watches the stranger mix his paints. Above them, on ceiling, spreads a pleasant view of the heavens.

dialogues.speaker: OHLENDORFF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They look up and imagine that if they'd lived back in his time, they wouldn’t have done what the others did. They would've stood by him. They wouldn't have run. His friends did, though. They would, too. As the painter is talking, scenes from Franz’s life flash through his mind:  38 39 40 aL 42 14.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIELD 38
dialogues.text: Franz sows a newly-ploughed field.

dialogues.speaker: OHLENDORFF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And I -- do I imitate him? No, I live off his life. I make a living by presenting him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIELD 39
dialogues.text: Franz works with his neighbors, remembers how they help e other here, neighbors depending on each other, like a fam and drawing closer to each other because of it. What else is there in life but getting closer to each oth

dialogues.speaker: OHLENDORFF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Others will look at this picture, and think that sympathizing with him -- being moved by his story -- will benefit them in the beyond.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIELDS 40
dialogues.text: Franz cuts wheat with a scythe, stopping from time to tim sharpen it with a whetstone he carries on his waist.

dialogues.speaker: OHLENDORFF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They’11 count themselves lucky that they didn’t live in times like ours, when your life might be demanded of you.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIELDS 41
dialogues.text: Franz threshes the wheat by hand.

dialogues.speaker: OHLENDORFF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Instead of suffering for the truth, I paint it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BARN 42
dialogues.text: The girls leap down from the hay loft onto the fresh stra

dialogues.speaker: OHLENDORFF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I turn the suffering of the brave into my livelihood. So people can look up from these pews and dream!  43 44 45 46 47 4g 49 15.

dialogues.speaker: J HOUSE 43
dialogues.text: Fani pulls a loaf of bread out of the oven.

dialogues.speaker: CHICKEN COOP 44
dialogues.text: A hen shelters her chicks.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BELL TOWER 45
dialogues.text: Franz cranks up the counterweights for the clock in the b tower.

dialogues.speaker: OHLENDORFF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I paint this comfortable man. A halo over his head. Some day I’11 paint the true one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz rings the bell. Its sound rolls out through the fie

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ST. R CHURCH 47
dialogues.text: Franz looks on a procession. The men carry banners and statues. A statue sits on a platform, set aside, ignored, seemingly looking on, with what emotion he cannot tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz remembers a man bent over a fresh grave by the chur weeping in the driving rain, spreading an umbrella to kee the water from soaking down into the freshly-turned sod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani in the fields, bent under a load of hay. She goes quietly about her tasks. Franz comes forward and kisses her. She wonders what has moved him to, out here in the open, just now.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: can I do anything for you? She shakes her head.  50 51 16. He sees his mother, her arms hardened by a life of ceasel labor, like the limbs of an old tree that has passed thro many a storm. He plays with the elder two girls, whom he has put up int tree to pick apples. They look down at him from the branc and laugh. Their little sister hugs his knees, clamoring be picked up. Franz takes Fani’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've always felt I didn’t have much to give you. But you took me. Even though T was a plain man.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: I took the best man I’ve ever known. How could he have loved anyone who came short of that mar

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Maybe others thought you could've done better.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Our children have a good father.

dialogues.speaker: RURAL SCENES
dialogues.text: Images flash through Franz’s mind. A plow breaking throug the earth. Oxen. Patient, resigned, as he waters them. A gaggle of geese. None strays far from the others. Taking up a jug of water he has left to cool in a shock o wheat, some bumblebees fly out. He laughs as he retreats, swatting them away. Hot metal hammered out at a blacksmith’s forge. Dusk. Cattle in the back of a truck, on their way to the slaughterhouse. They stir and stamp, uneasily. INT. POOR WOMAN’S COTTAGE 51 Franz cleans the cottage of a poor old woman, an invalid. prepares a meal for her and cheers her with his conversat Someone rarely visited by others.  52 53 54 55 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz sits alone at the end of the day, drinking a beer. His neighbors are gathered nearby. The mayor. The blacksm and farrier. The policeman. The clerk. They sing old songs. Franz does not join in.

dialogues.speaker: SPRING FESTIVAL 53
dialogues.text: Radegund celebrates the Fasching festival. The people gather in a procession to drive out winter and prepare for the return of spring. They wear carved wooden masks, with crowns of flowers on their heads. They ring cowbells and dance. Why would he set himself at odds with those whom he has g up to cherish -- to whom he owes every consideration?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz passes a neighbor on his way home through the field

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler! Franz ignores him. The neighbor frowns, waiting for an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Pfui Hitler! The neighbor looks around to see if anyone has heard, the goes silently on his way. Franz trembles all over; his he is in his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz is tidying up around the church when he sees Fr. Fiirthauer, the young pastor of the parish. He has taken place of another priest, Fr. Josef Karobath, who, a few y earlier, was jailed for giving an anti-Nazi sermon, and subsequently banished from the district. Fr. Fiirthauer h good reason to be careful about what he says to this trou young man coming to him for guidance.  18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz finishes ringing the bell. No one has come to mass today. They are alone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Father -- I'm troubled -- if I’m called up, I can’t serve. We are killing innocent people. Raiding other countries. Preying on the weak. And the priests call them heroes, even saints —- the soldiers that do this.

dialogues.speaker: FR. FURTHAUER
dialogues.text: Have you spoken with anyone else? Your wife? Your family? (Franz shakes his head) Don’t you think you ought to consider the consequences of your actions -- for them? Fiirthauer is wary of Franz, who might after all be a Ges agent, trying to see if he can extract some incautious wo from the priest.

dialogues.speaker: FR. FURTHAUER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'd almost surely be shot.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FR. FURTHAUER
dialogues.text: Your sacrifice would benefit no one.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: You might be right. More I fear that I might do--

dialogues.speaker: FR. FURTHAUER
dialogues.text: Wrong? Which is the greater wrong?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Speak freely, Father.

dialogues.speaker: FR. FURTHAUER
dialogues.text: I have often wished that I might act on all I believe. But I have to think whom I might harm -- why do you look at me that way? You'd be taking your own life.  57 58 59 19.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: If it were that —-

dialogues.speaker: FR. FURTHAUER
dialogues.text: I'll speak with the Bishop about your case. A wiser man than I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest takes Franz aside.

dialogues.speaker: FR. FURTHAUER
dialogues.text: No Catholic who refuses military service will get any support from his spiritual leaders. You know that, don’t you? Can you blame them? For all they know you might be a Gestapo agent coming to trap them with your questions -- to lead them into an act of treason: To bring the wrath of the State down on our Church. They'd arrest any confessor who showed the slightest sign of sympathy for such inclinations. Franz searches his eyes. Is the priest really in sympathy with him and just can’t say so openly?

dialogues.speaker: FR. FURTHAUER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What can one do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, as Franz passes through the village, it seems to him that his neighbors might not all be as happy, or as close he once imagined. That man in the woods. The cry of a lunatic woman he hear one evening across a field from a distant, darkened house swifts chase each other through the streets. The sky is f of their cries. EXT. COUSIN’S FARMHOUSE 59 Franz debates with his cousin whether he should refuse military service or not. He still hasn’t told Fani about qualms.  60 61 62 63 64 20. His cousin warns him not to speak about the matter with others in the village. There are jealous, angry people. A few. They might report him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz has told her. She pretends this is a question they not face.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: (after a silence) They won’t call you up. They need farmers. How else are people going to eat? INT. GIRL’S BEDROOM 61 They look at the girls asleep in their beds.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ask, and you'll be answered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Fani prepares their bed and lays out his clothes. seems that she is making every effort to be kind and thoughtful, as though it were suddenly clear to her how precious her husband is to her, though her devotion to hi has been more than apparent already.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN 63
dialogues.text: The Postman rides by on his bicycle, rings his bell and waves. Franz and Fani wait in fear and suspense every tim appears. He might deliver the same induction notice to Fr that his neighbor Hessler received.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother and son muck out the stalls.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: what is it, mother?

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: Will you not spare your family? Do you hate your wife? Your children?  65 66 21.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: Did I bring you into the world for this?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Who's been talking with you?

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: How would she maintain the farm? With three young children. How would she plow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz and Fani weed the orchard.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: I went up to the mountains. They tell me what to do. The river does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz has come up to the high mountains on his motorcycle There is a sudden silence when he shuts the engine off. High above stand the inaccessible peaks. The eternal snow rock. Below, the peaceful sound of a river, flowing nearb distant cowbell. The bluebells and vetch. Clover. Fireweed. Negligence; vacancy. Peace. Why not always? 0, for the wings of a dove! To fly far from trouble and grief! To his wife Franz presents a face of confidence and stren but inwardly he is assailed with torment, doubt and fear. From time to time we hear him inwardly expressing those feelings or recalling his past, to strengthen himself aga them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ 0.S., (INTERIOR VOICE)
dialogues.text: My wife! You seemed like someone come from heaven. Humble. Kind. Through your eyes you sent a sweetness into my heart.  67 68 69 70 22.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ 0.S., (INTERIOR VOICE)
dialogues.text: You make me feel I have no enemy in all the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani’s sister takes Franz aside.

dialogues.speaker: RESIE
dialogues.text: You took Fani’s happiness into your hands. She might have had other men. Not many besides you would think it a duty to add to their troubles this way. An image of the onrushing train passes through Franz’s mi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz and Fani have come to Linz to meet with the Bishop. They look up in awe as they enter the cathedral. The orga is practising a hymn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz paces back and forth. Bishop Fliessen has kept them waiting for more than an hour.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: The Bishop will be with you shortly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz bows to the Bishop, who holds out his hand and, aft some pleasantries, moves quickly to business.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: You have a responsibility -- to those within your private circle. Your family! Have you had a personal revelation from above? Was your conscience told to ignore the instruction of those responsible for your spiritual guidance?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: I’m not sure.  23.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Not sure? I have a responsibility for the souls of your parish. It weighs heavily on me. I wouldn't be able to sleep were I either to keep silent -- or to speak out at the wrong time. Each of us must fulfill his duty -- willingly, loyally -- devote himself wholly to the service of his Fatherland... You know the words of the Apostle: let every man be subject to the powers placed over him,

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: And if our leader is -- a monster — - what does one do?

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Our home’s at stake. Our people Be a man. Be strong... Our Leader knows war's horror. He himself was a soldier at the front. He tried to spare Europe from this conflict. But there was no avoiding it. Our enemies would make us slaves. oA INT. WAITING ROOM 71 Fani paces back and forth. When Franz comes out of the consulting room, he looks sad, or fearful

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) I think he was afraid -- that I might be a spy. He said we have to obey. But that was in other times. When there were clergy who could be obeyed -- They don’t dare commit themselves. Or it could be their turn next. (later) They're flesh and blood, as we are. They can be weak. Maybe they’re even more tempted.  72 73 74 15 76 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz sees a group of monks tending a garden, smiling and chatting amiably. It seems they have no trouble with thei conscience. They live unperturbed by the world. Fani wraps her arms around him -- determined to support h not to insist on herself, but they do have three girls. Perhaps he will be exempted if ever he is called to milit service, or assigned to a hospital job. Perhaps he would accept such a position. Perhaps he won't be called at all

dialogues.speaker: HITLER, (NEWSREEL)
dialogues.text: Images of Hitler, his face half-seen.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What difference will it make? He'll go on doing as he pleases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk home in silence, Franz’s heart full to bursting

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You didn’t make the world the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls run out to greet them. Rosalia looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are working in the fields when Franz’s mother turns him.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: Good children obey. Their mother and father only want what’s good for them. They know it. If they work hard, they can buy a house with a garden —- live happily to the end of their days. (after a pause) A man brings his wages home to his wife.  1 78 25.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She puts them away, so that if ever they get sick, they can be nursed at home and won't need charity -- to raise their children or live into old age. People get what they deserve. Bad workmen come to bad ends. Fani glancing up -- sees a sow’s carcass, hanging from a outside the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz trembles inwardly. What does his honor require of h It seems that no one can tell him the answer. He alone mu decide. Never has he felt so alone -- he who has always b so close to his family, his neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz sits in the beer garden, surrounded by friends, including the Mayor and the Policeman.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: He got us into this war. The young men are gone —-

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR KRAUS
dialogues.text: He did what he had to. He wasn’t content to watch his nation go under. He saw what we'd become. No destiny. Everyone chasing after comfort, success. No ideals.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKSMITH SPITZ
dialogues.text: .+.Breaking into homes! Tearing the earrings off women’s ears. My mother’s old. I hope she dies soon.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR KRAUS
dialogues.text: People saw that a fraud had been perpetrated against us. We found out that liberalism is a sham. Democracy. A mask for the commercial spirit. If we don’t lift the youth out of this swamp, they’1l drown in it. The Mayor is a member of the Nazi party. Franz has looked to him since he was a child. No ones dares to contradict  79 80 81 82 26.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR KRAUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's be glad democracy has died. See where it led us! To deadlock. Paralysis. Slaves of the rich! It has no strength to stop the crisis. Hitler is a new era. A new truth. (turning to Franz) Your father would have stood here and told you the same. He was in the war. He fought! What did he die for? In the trenches! The mu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor addresses a gathering of men in SA uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR KRAUS
dialogues.text: Flame, teach us! Light us! Show us the road! There’s no way back! Flame, ignite! Hearts, burn!

dialogues.speaker: THE FON 80
dialogues.text: The Féhn blows over the fields -- a dry, burning wind, th melts the snow and clears the skies. Avalanches are loose The risk of fire is great. Everyone is on the alert, in a state of nervous expectation.

dialogues.speaker: ECKINGER
dialogues.text: The snow looks clear. We might be able to send the flocks up early.

Franz debates what he should do. Omens of death flash thr his mind; an open door, a curtain beyond which he cannot a scythe cutting through the hay, the Salzach’s far shore Evil takes on so many disguises. His conscience is restle He vacillates. No one can give him any advice in these circumstances, even his own bishop. All that was familiar to him now seems far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men in Nazi uniforms have come by the house to seek his family’s contribution to a collection they are making on behalf of the war effort.  83 84 27. Franz looks at them, says nothing. The men go away; astonished. This will set tongues wagging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz hears a knock on the door. He opens to find the May standing before him.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR KRAUS
dialogues.text: You have refused to contribute to our collection on behalf of the veterans! Their families! This has clearly fanned the flame of suspicion in the community.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR KRAUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That is not like you. (after a pause) I also hear that you have refused to accept the family allowance, and other subsidies, that the State would generously have provided you. Why? Are you afraid to fight? Your father. A brave * man. You never knew him. You were just a boy. I know what he would * expect of you. Fani listens from the next room, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz holds his hands out to the youngest girl. She teete towards him. It hasn’t been long since she took her first steps. From up in a tree, the older two girls drop apples down t their mother. She catches them in her apron. Franz walks by the Salzach. The river flows peacefully al whispering, murmuring -- what? What does it tell him? He wishes for some oracle; clear voice. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows his head in the field with his wife as the angelu rings in the Tittmoning church, to the west. * They dig up potatoes, tiny figures in the vast landscape. Fani sings as she works. Peasant faces. Baked by the sun.  28. Their hearts cringe at the sign of the Postman, who rings bell as he rides by and gives them a friendly wave. They not comfortable until he is gone. The thud of cattle’s hooves ring through the walls of the barn. It stands next to the house where they sleep, so th can profit from the animals’ warmth A scarecrow. Geese. The sound of a rooster. Light struggl through the slats of the barn doors Franz digs a grave. The churchyard is silent, except for sound of his shovel. Empty, silent, still. Where does his duty lie? Franz digs out a well. Fani’s voice is indistinct as, in light thirty feet above, she speaks with a neighbor. He l up toward the blank, featureless sky. What would it be li to be away from her, forever buried in the earth this way Water gathers at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Franz -- you know how proud you are! How stubborn! Make sure it isn’t -- that. The truth is, he can’t be sure if his defiance is inspire conscience, or instead by pride. She touches a nerve. Is it a sign that you are right with your conscience that everything goes smoothly for you? The ticking of a clock. A train whistle, far away. Franz trembles under the burden of his decision. FANI (CONT’D) Are you taking on too much? What can we do? The world is stronger. Fani looks away. Surely it will not come to a crisis. She believes if they are good, everything will come out right This is what she tells the children at bedtime. FANI (CONT’D) Quiet now! Don’t fight! Sleep! (whispering to the eldest) Every day’s not Sunday. Every day you won’t have sunshine. But every day you're dear to us. Franz listens, from the next room.  85 86 87 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani and her sister weave hay into a drying rack. Later, ride their bicycles home.

dialogues.speaker: RESIE
dialogues.text: Does anyone else know? Just the priest? His mother looks at me coldly. Like I was to blame. 1 want what you want. I can’t bear that he makes you suffer. He makes a choice for you, too.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RESIE
dialogues.text: Does he know what he’s doing to you? Tell him! Pride! That’s what it is.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: No, I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: RESIE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you resist -- fight with him? You do nothing to stand in his way. He does what he likes -- with your happiness.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: I trust him.

dialogues.speaker: RESIE
dialogues.text: Is he just stubborn? FRANZ’S POV ON RESIE 86 Resie does not speak to Franz as they pass each other by. Franz is left to guess why. He risks cutting himself not from his community, but from his family as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz walks though the alms, the high summer pastures whe the farmers bring their cattle up to graze. He enters a deserted village. He looks around, puzzled. w have the others gone? There is no one else in sight.  88 89 90 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz talks with his neighbor Spitz, the Blacksmith, as h pounds a blade out on an anvil. *

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: If you don’t think well of me, never mind. That’s neither here nor there.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKSMITH SPITZ
dialogues.text: Don’t make things worse for yourself. The horse may have a heavy load, but it won’t help him to throw it over into a ditch when it’s his own feed... * Till now it hasn’t occurred to Franz that any of his neighbors would consider such a thing.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKSMITH SPITZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t sail into the wind. Wait for the storm to subside. Then you can do your good. Your wife will be destitute -- Your mother will have no fire in the winter. *

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: We're going to pay for these crimes.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKSMITH SPITZ
dialogues.text: You won't forget the evenings we played together in the fields. Till the dark came down. You loved * us all! We were friends together. * Take a friend’s advice. Leave well * alone. You come too late. There's nothing we can do. (seeing Franz unmoved) Well, then I leave you to your fate. Let’s not quarrel. I only * tell you what you already know.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN 89
dialogues.text: The sight of their children playing with a duck fills the mother with dread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz has come to visit Fiirthauer, the priest.  31.

dialogues.speaker: FR. FURTHAUER
dialogues.text: Don’t say it. (after a pause) Does a man have the right to let himself be put to death for the truth? We can’t all be martyrs — Could it possibly please God? - an act that would destroy your family’s happiness? (Franz looks away) I know you were closer to my predecessor. Perhaps you had more faith in -- his judgement.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Ah, Fr. Karobath! He smoked. He liked wine. He liked to hunt, but he never came back with anything. He was a bad shot. We teased him. Gradually, the voice of the priest becomes that of the painter who was restoring the ceiling of the church.

dialogues.speaker: OHLENDORFF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The trouble with Christians is that no one wants to kill them anymore. There was a time when you'd be afraid to say you followed him, because it meant so much. Now it means nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz sees how the neighbors treat Fani coldly. Radegund turned against them. Their home! Those whom they love!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani can tell there is something on her husband’s mind. S dreads what it might be. She avoids speaking with him abo it, as though by saying nothing he might in time forget t new whims and come to his senses.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Are the children asleep?  93

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Did they say anything to you? I saw them speaking to you by the road.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: They said their husbands have gone off. To war. Why should they fight to save us?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Did they hurt you? With their words?

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Are you crying?

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: I never cry. It gives me a headache.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: I know. Franz blows out the candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93 Franz has brought a load of oats to Trakl, the miller. Th step outside by the water wheel as the grain is separated from the chaff.

dialogues.speaker: TRAKL
dialogues.text: If we could just see the beginning of his kingdom. If we could see only the sun of his kingdom rise. But -- Christ came and went. Nothing happened. Years go by, so many years. And nothing. Nothing ever! (over the thud of the wheel) So hard to make the good grow up. One spark is all that’s needed to set the field on fire. A single match.

dialogues.speaker: TRAKL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It takes months to lay it out -- to plough, to plant it -- more work to make a crop, and then the sword takes one minute. We’re the party of the plough. They're the party of the sword. We'll always be beaten. Never has the kingdom of perdition spread so far. A flood! We have to learn how to live in this flood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani and Resie walk down the furrows, each with a sickle, cutting the bad weeds out of the wheat.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: He’ll get an exemption. I know it. They need farmers. They gather the bad weeds in bundles and burn them. The g they bring into the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The postman rings. Fani and Franz look up with a start. They go out to meet him. He hands them a letter in an official envelope, looking away as he does. Franz rocks, like a tree in the wind. They go away from the children, out to the field in back the house, beneath the apple tree. There he opens the envelope. It is what they thought.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: You could hide in the woods! I could bring you food! We could run away, to the mountains, where nobody could find us. To Switzerland.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: The border is closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Others have heard of his refusal.  34.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR KRAUS
dialogues.text: You know what this means. Not only for your family. For the whole town! You'll be hanged. Your wife and children will have no one to support them. Your mother will die unconsoled.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ'S MOTHER 97
dialogues.text: His mother looks at him in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: Is this how you repay us? Her will is set against his.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've thrown away everything you had and gone down a step in life —— when your father gave you the means of rising.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: We differ, mother. I’m sorry. But I'm grateful to you for wishing me the best.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: I have no more to say. I only hope your own children make you a better return for the pains you've spent on them. None of us can imagine how you could get into such a position when you’re so law- abiding. It’s a riddle. I’m an old woman, and the additional work will be considerable. How could I ever have imagined that, in the evening of my life, things would turn out this way? Haven’t we had trouble enough already? Without inventing more?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: Let’s say no more. His spirit rises a little at her certainty that she is in right and wishes her to lecture him.  35.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: I know it seems to you I’m doing the worst to people I wish the best for. But they haven't given up on me. I don’t see why you should.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: Young people are blind to everything but their own wishes. They seldom imagine how much those wishes cost others. You've thrown yourself away -- made their Sacrifices vain. Let us say no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An image flashes through Franz’s mind of the train he dre of -- its power, its onrushing force -- carrying them all their ruin.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Mother, your life has been hard enough. I would never do anything to bring you needless -- pain.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: Trust me enough to know the reasons. Why people who have been loyal to you shouldn't expect loyalty in return?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: You taught me: be brave, be true.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: Not just to yourself. Can you imagine how they are treated -- your wife, your children?

dialogues.speaker: FANI AND FRANZ 98
dialogues.text: Fani draws Franz’s arm around her waist. Are they not one

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The local Policeman, his friend, approaches Franz on find him alone.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: I've known you since you were a boy. Spare me the pain of arresting you.  100 101 102 36. Franz seems to nod. The Policeman never imagined he might find himself in this position. The war has come home to S Radegund, though many a neighbor has already been called service and half a dozen have died.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, ALONE 100
dialogues.text: The man who hasn’t given himself to the truth completely hasn't really given himself -- is that so?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ 0.S., (INTERIOR VOICE)
dialogues.text: Mother, how I loved you! Your strength. Unbroken... By sorrow, grief... How I wished that I could lift it from your shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ WITH THE CHILDREN 101
dialogues.text: Franz plays with the children.

dialogues.speaker: ROSI
dialogues.text: Hold me up -- I can touch the ceiling! He does this. She boasts to her younger sisters that she done something they could never achieve. They quarrel, ti Fani separates them. Husband and wife look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Come, girls. Your father’s going away. On -- a journey.

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: Where? How long?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Not very long.

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: Will you bring us something?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around the house, fearful it might be for the la time. Resie has come to take care of the children.  103 104 105 106 107 108 37.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: We'll go quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz and Fani walk through the village. They exchange courteous greetings with their neighbors, who assume that Franz has put aside his rumored qualms and that he is now going off, like others before him, to assume his duties t the fatherland.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: (to Fani, in a whisper) I haven't said anything. There'd be quarrels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz and Fani walk in silence through the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross over the river.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Are you afraid?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace each other, well out of the sight of others. sound of an approaching train fills them with dread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is gone. Fani wanders the platform; lost, alone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani and Resie yoke up the cows. They note their neighbor the distance.

dialogues.speaker: RESIE
dialogues.text: They think he went off because he decided to serve. That he is with the troops.  109 110 ql 38.

dialogues.speaker: RESIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (after a pause) I hate men.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: The Policeman bows to Fani.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. I don’t know how I would've done it. Neighbors tell her how glad they are that Franz has chang his mind. She does nothing to undeceive them. Nor does sh tell the children. She looks up sharply at a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz approaches the barracks in Enns, a city not far fro Radegund. A line of conscripts snakes out the front door older men along with teenagers. INT. ENNS BARRACKS, RECEPTION AREA qi Franz’s heart pounds in his ears. He approaches a young CAPTAIN sitting at a desk at the front of the line.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN HERDER
dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Jagerstatter

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN HERDER
dialogues.text: From -~

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: St. Radegund. Upper Donau.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN HERDER
dialogues.text: Age?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN HERDER
dialogues.text: Children? (Franz nods) Names.  39.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Rosalia. Maria... Aloisia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men have lined up to take their oath to Hitler. Franz gathers his courage, says nothing as the others speak.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN HERDER
dialogues.text: You. I didn’t hear you. Step out of the line. You will not take the oath? You refuse? Franz nods. The Captain looks at him; -- puzzled, not ang almost embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN HERDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you understand what you are doing? He motions to a pair of soldiers to take Franz away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz is led down a row of cells. The prisoners look at h curious about the nature of his crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz is put in a cell with four other prisoners, Frenchm from the Lorraine: Andro, Levan, Max and Ermin.

dialogues.speaker: CELLMATE MAX
dialogues.text: We wouldn't take the oath. They gave us 10 years hard labor. They are taken with Franz’s smile. He will find him hones quiet, helpful -- ready to give them his last piece of br from the meals they take in their cell, and satisfy himse with a little black coffee. 11s EXT. PRISON COURTYARD (LINZ/ENNS) 11s The prisoners are allowed a morning walk. Ten times aroun the yard.

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: You love your country? (Franz nods) Why won't you serve?  116 117 40.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: This war is senseless. Cruel. Doomed.

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: Others do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: You'll be executed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Better than do others’ evil. and die anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The routine of the prison. Rise at 6, breakfast at 7, cle the cell, a few gymnastics. Whispered conversation. Tappi at the wall. Notes passed behind the backs of the guards.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dearest wife! Warmest greetings from my new residence. I have 24 hours in this place behind me. I will be here for the duration of my interrogation. So far it hasn’t been bad. There are five of us in this cell. So many foreigners! The food is not bad. There is no need for you to be concerned about my physical well-being. When we submit ourselves to God’s will, everything turns out for the good. May things come about as He wants. If only they go well for you! Franz sits with his eyes closed. The guards taunt him, as a number of his fellow prisoners. (Improvised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani shears the sheep. No one from the village comes forw to help her. She sees them in the distance, nods. They lo away. At first they assumed that Franz had given up his scruple gone off to answer his induction notice and serve with th troops. It must be that they begun to learn the truth.  118 41. Fani cuts the hay and rakes it out in aromatic rows. Litt Rosi helps her mother drag a harrow through an uncultivat field. They bend their backs like beasts of burden. INT. INTERROGATION ROOM (LINZ/ENNS) ue * Franz is led into a meeting room with a hundred chairs an long table. He marvels at this world unlike any he has ev known,

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN HERDER
dialogues.text: (to the guard) You may leave us alone. He strides back and forth. He never looks directly at Fra

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN HERDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The company commander isn’t here. What good do you imagine your defiance is doing anyone? (no reply) Do you expect to change the course of things? Do you think the authorities are aware of you? That your protest will come to their attention? That anyone will know of it? Ever hear you? Do you think it will influence some decision? No one knows what goes on here. Behind these walls. What purpose does it serve? His voice is calm and measured. There is no shouting; no abuse. Franz is surprised, a little pleased

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN HERDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you alone wise? Do you know something I don’t? Tell me what that is. (no reply) Do you think it matters to God? Do you think you matter to him? Then * why are you here? He looks out the window, waiting for Franz to speak. CAPTAIN HERDER (CONT’D) * Your God does nothing. Would I * pray to a spider? Poor man. No individual bears a responsibility for all this. That responsibility * belongs to one man. He stands alone.  42.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: I won't follow his evil orders... Does it make no difference whether this war is just or unjust?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN HERDER
dialogues.text: Has heaven told you this? what * does your priest say? Your bishop? Franz must be careful not to compromise them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: We can’t simply ask what our bishop would do. We have to ask what our conscience says to this. It’s hard to find the right path now, when the signposts have been blown around by the wind. Our * spiritual leaders -- are silent. *

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN HERDER
dialogues.text: They might have their reasons. I * tell you this as someone who is kindly disposed toward you. Do you judge me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: I can’t look into another man’s heart. I judge no one. 119 EXT. COURTYARD 11g Franz is led back to his cell. The guards are bored. Ther no Gestapo here, no SS. This is a provincial jail, and th matter is a small one in the great scheme of things.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ 0.S., (INTERIOR VOICE)
dialogues.text: I waited... No one else seemed troubled in the same way. It seemed they knew something that I * didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz talks with a cellmate, Carlo.

dialogues.speaker: CARLO
dialogues.text: A good war. For them to make money on. I’ve seen lots of things since I was_a boy. It only gets worse. They leave the poor man behind. This is the big folks’ world.  43.

dialogues.speaker: CARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When the ship goes down, it’s the boys in the engine room who go first.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: What did you do before you got there?

dialogues.speaker: CARLO
dialogues.text: A robber age. The law is: rob or be robbed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Do you have a family? Carlo shakes his head. He has no way of learning the uncertainty Franz feels. Franz is alone, in many ways.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My wife. My children. Lead me. Tell me what I should do.

dialogues.speaker: CARLO
dialogues.text: I see no use for the church. It’s left the stage. Each man has to find his way alone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ,
dialogues.text: How have you?

dialogues.speaker: CARLO
dialogues.text: If I had, I wouldn’t be here. But it makes me sick to see men get down on their knees. The church is a whorehouse. The whole idea of it =- loathsome, low. As if men got down in the mud to worship. They never get down on their real knees. Myself, I bow to nothing. The image of the train, which has haunted Franz from the beginning, passes quickly before his mind’s eye. The engi shovelling coal into the firebox. The pistons, the interweaving tracks. CARLO (CONT’D) How can you cast your care on him - = or make him your hope? Look what happened to him! The same will happen to you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz goes about his daily routine. The prisoners are rou up for a walk in the courtyard. They empty out their slop buckets, are given bread and beans, and a wooden spoon to them with.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from a letter) Dearest wife, I am once again grateful for all of the love and faithfulness and sacrifice that you have shown me and the whole family -- and that you are continuing to show me. It will also be a difficult sacrifice not to have someone with whom you can be angry and perhaps not to have anyone who will hurt you. Love requires it, always striving for more perfection. It will become easier for you. At least you know to whom you can entrust your hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani helps a poor woman, a widow who lives on the outskir of St. Radegund. The widow is grateful to Fani, while oth regard her with suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Forgive everyone, including me, if you suffer because of me. Help the poor for as long as you can... Don’t be angry with mother even if she does not understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz gives his letter to one of his cellmates, who hides away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This letter will leave here this morning with a cellmate who is being released. It will come to you without being censored. You Should not give testimony to anyone.  45.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If someone asks you if you agree with my decision not to fight, only say how it has been most difficult for you. You cannot lighten things for me. New officers interrogate Franz. They try to trap him with trick questions, but still there is no physical abuse, if anything, they find a strange curiosity about him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I have no fear of the officials. If I did, I wouldn't be here. I want to save my life, but not through lies. They try to trap me with trick questions. It hasn’t been easy to stick with my decision. It may become more difficult.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: What did your priest say?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: To report for military service.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Do you know better than he?

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I had to keep silent concerning his words, or he would no longer be free... One runs into bitter, disillusioned men. Men who broke various kinds of laws. It is horrible, what they have suffered. For the slightest offense, they are imprisoned for years. But it is all forgiven if one agrees to fight on the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three girls play in the yard. Loisi turns to her moth

dialogues.speaker: LOIST
dialogues.text: When will Father be home? Will he bring sausage? The two older girls look puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerie Pachner and August Diehl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerie Pachner and August Diehl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August DiehI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August DiehI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ae" August Diehl and Valerie Pachner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August Diehl and Valerie Pachner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August Diehl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerie Pachner and August Dieh!  46.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Her older sisters understand that you can’t come home so quickly. Maridi prays for you. (the child, praying) Rosl even makes small sacrifices (She hides a doll in a tree) so that our loving Father will bring you home soon. She sang a song for you -- wondered if you could hear. I write about only the good things that your children do. You already know their lesser traits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls bicker, push each other.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We haven't yet told the children where you are. I have told only the pastor about your situation. Breinbauer died March ist, in combat. A son of the Hofbauers is missing. (war scenes; stock) How do you find yourself spiritually? Do you find solace? Writing to you now, in your current situation, makes me terribly sad. I still had a small hope that you would change your mind because you have compassion for me and know that I cannot help being as I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz paces his cell. A moan of despair comes faintly to ears.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I fear you suffer much because of me, dear wife. Forgive me for everything I have done wrong. Don’t be concerned about me. The food and the conditions here are good. Franz overhears his neighbors, wrangling with each other.

dialogues.speaker: CELLMATE MAX
dialogues.text: Why not? Tell me: why not? Get it out of my mind, into my body.  47.

dialogues.speaker: CELLMATE MAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why not’s what I say. Mind over matter. I’ve seen things. Know things. I know their weakness.

dialogues.speaker: CELLMATE ERMIN
dialogues.text: They see a weak spot, they go for it. Now I think before I do stuff. They didn’t read me my rights. They said I didn’t comply. Only dogs are free.

dialogues.speaker: CELLMATE MAX
dialogues.text: I don’t get the point of things.

dialogues.speaker: CELLMATE ERMIN
dialogues.text: I got thrown off the train the rest of them are riding on. Now I've got to crawl back up a hill of broken glass, get back on that train going a thousand miles an hour. Work my way from the cattle car up. I blame myself.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We could use you here for work. Especially to break in the calf. The calf refuses to be harnessed. Fani has to run to catc it. Swaying its head, it knocks her to the ground, then l at her with innocent, apologetic eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Twice it was harnessed to the manure spreader and pulled it here and there. When there’s no one else, one must think about everything. If only you could come home to cultivate the oats... to rake the hay! Fani gathers brushwood from the forest. She moves though dark woods, looking for dead limbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani and Franz’s mother carry water from a stream. The we has run dry. Rosalia’s frustration grows when her bucket spills on the ground.  48.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: Now they know.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: The others. Everyone. Someone must have told them. Your sister!

dialogues.speaker: FANT
dialogues.text: She would never say anything.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Our well has run out of water. We have to carry water with buckets. If you could come home to improve things... We don’t trust ourselves in the well, so it still is full of mud... Already we need rain to cultivate the oats. Greetings from your three little women. The girls play nearby, unaware of their grandmother's mounting displeasure with Fani.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They say to tell you only about the good things they are doing. of course! But I would not surprise you by telling you about their disobedience.

dialogues.speaker: MARIDI
dialogues.text: If pappa comes home, we won’t fight anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When, at the end of the day, Fani goes to close the door, youngest daughter cries out. LOIsT Don’t lock it!

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LOIST
dialogues.text: When he comes home -- he won’t be able to get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One must accept everything that He sends us with gratitude. He loves us. He won't send us more than we can bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosalia’s hostility has grown to a settled disposition.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: Do you tell him? Everything?

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Write him yourself.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: My hand would tremble. I’m afraid that, when he’s gone, I’11 hate him for it. I, his own mother!

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Today we finished the cultivation of the oats. The calf now walks with such ease that it can be with the cows. The weather is lovely, and so we have much to do. I remain continually concerned about you. Warm greetings from your loving wife, Fani! Greetings, too, from mother, sister and the children! Be well. See you again!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two neighbor women pass Fani on the road.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Why do you look at me that way?

dialogues.speaker: FRAU PATE
dialogues.text: We know.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: What is it? What?

dialogues.speaker: FRAU PATE
dialogues.text: Our husbands fight so you can be safe? They look at her with cold, unforgiving eyes. 129 130  131 132 133 134 50. FRAU PATE (CONT’D) An act of madness. A sin against his family. His village!

dialogues.speaker: 2ND WOMAN
dialogues.text: His church.

dialogues.speaker: FRAU PATE
dialogues.text: You kept it a secret.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND WOMAN
dialogues.text: An uneducated farmer.

dialogues.speaker: FRAU PATE
dialogues.text: He'll be forgotten. They leave Fani, fighting back her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving her cart through the main square, Fani is treated the cold stares of neighbors whose warm greetings she has been accustomed to.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, MILL 132
dialogues.text: As she gives her grain to Trakl, the miller, she lowers h eyes in confusion and shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A water wheel drives the mill. Fani watches as the grain separated from the chaff.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, MILL 134
dialogues.text: Trakl loads the sacks of milled grain back onto her cart.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: But -- You've given me back -- more than I gave you. He does not meet her eyes. He bows in silence. Fani goes away, moved.  51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz calms a cellmate who is trembling and shaking with and despair.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now my little ones! Dear Rosl, Maridl and Loisi. Thank you for praying for me. It will bring me great joy if I am able to see you again soon. I urge you not to quarrel. Also, do not lie. I believe the heavenly Father will bring it about that I shall come home to you. Since this won’t happen soon, Mother must be able to lock the door at night. I shall come home during the day. And dear wife, have you brought in the straw from the pasture? Yesterday I saw buds on an apricot tree. My three girls will already be running barefoot and picking flowers. It would be better to tell them where their father is than to tell them stories. and, dear wife, I wish to ask something of you. Would it be possible to put some pieces of edelweiss in the next letter? A cellmate here requested that I get him some -- a young Frenchman condemned to death a few weeks ago. He would like to send edelweiss to his beloved as a farewell gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani scrapes in the darkness at the bottom of a well. Res looks down from above. They both are covered with mud

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The well went dry on Thursday. We dug it out. Now we need a good rain. At the moment we must carry our water. Here are some violets, though they will be dead by the time you get them. The children, when they see beautiful flowers, immediately want to send them to their father, who will laugh when he receives them.  137 138 52. They carry water home in pails.

dialogues.speaker: ROSALIA
dialogues.text: (to the sisters) You should've dug it out. You waited!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strohofer, a neighbor, gives the sisters a ride in his wa When Fani' goes to pay him, he shakes his head. Resie is to tears by this small kindness. It seems not everyone in village has turned against them.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Strohofer gave us a ride to Tittmoning. He did not demand payment and would not accept any. Greetings to you in God, most beloved husband. They cut sedge grass from the banks of the Salzach river.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Many think things aren't going well for you. Though I can’t help you and can send you nothing, I would like to visit you, if only for a few minutes. I don’t know whether I may. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sisters put up straw.

dialogues.speaker: FANT
dialogues.text: I tried to get in touch with the fortress. They don’t answer. My husband loves his country. They don’t answer the phone! When T can even get a signal. How do you get their attention? Who are they accountable to? You can’t get at them. There’s nobody to connect the call. If you get someone, he’s not the one in charge. Resie has now come to live with Fani, to help with the fa They are more and more cut off from life in the community Neighbors pass by, without exchanging a word, eyeing them coldly.  139 53. Fani thinks of the fortress -- remote, dark and incomprehensible. The place where their fates will be decided. FANI (CONT’D) They don’t explain! Anything! why should they be in charge? why -- should they run the world? Did they ask him if he would accept work in a hospital? We don’t want any favors from them. Just his rights.

dialogues.speaker: RESIE
dialogues.text: How was it when you went?

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: So strange! At first I couldn't find anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the fortress, the narrow streets are curiously deserted. There are small buildings here and there, the plaster flaking off the walls. The battlements are crumbl from neglect. Everyone Fani meets is amiable enough, but no one seems t know the name of the official she asks to speak with. At she arrives at the office of a Major Kiel. He sits behind desk. A corporal in an S.S. uniform plays Mozart in the n room.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR KIEL
dialogues.text: Here you are! Take a seat. Tell me your wishes! (shuffling his papers) Ah, I remember. The whole business! Now that you've been so kind as to visit, I must tell you the truth of the matter. I see nothing this department can do. But I will send your papers along to Linz. Let’s see, where are they? His desk is overflowing with papers, bundles of them.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR KIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s always business left undone. Things to put away.  140 141 142 54. MAJOR KIEL (CONT’ You can be sure your case will be treated with the greatest understanding. Why don’t we say that when we've given it all our proper attention, we'll send for you? The Colonel must be consulted.

dialogues.speaker: FANT
dialogues.text: May I meet with him?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR KIEL
dialogues.text: Ah, Madame, he can’t meet with everyone! A busy man! But phone. Make an appointment!

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: I've tried to. My call isn’t answered.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR KIEL
dialogues.text: That surprises me. The problem must be on your end. The telephone works quite well up here. It speeds up our work. But there’s no fixed connection, I know. And sometimes, these lazy fellows leave the receiver off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: Then how can I make an appointment? You don’t answer my letters. It took me two days to get here. A difficult journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldier playing the piano has stopped to talk with Fa Fani feels herself in a labyrinth, a soulless world, with way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Fani wanders through the courtyard, the officials avoi her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fani hears a distant bell. She looks up towards the fortr The stone walls stand dark and indifferent.  143 She looks up with awe.Strange, uncanny, remote and demonically illogical.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I advise you not to visit at this time. Maybe later. I still have not received a trial. Most people think that things are bad for me here, but we get enough to eat. They did not lock us up to make us fat. Things could be worse. 55. cruel, A petty, obstinate, unaccountable bureaucracy of document and procedures; a hierarchy of fearful men.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You know, dear wife, that I do not engage in this struggle in order to make my life wonderful. As long as I don’t lose my faith, nothing can be unfortunate. Our sadness will be changed to joy. All this, in relation to eternity, is less than half a second. Who are they, these men -- this authority that she reach?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: can never 143 Franz remembers when he rode his motorcycle where he plea His was the first motorcycle in the village. Everyone cam out to look at him. He was a wild one then. He played car bowled, danced. He had just come back from working in the mines, full of life and hope. It was then that he first m Fani:

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ
dialogues.text: Who do you have the next dance with?

dialogues.speaker: FANI
dialogues.text: With you -- if you will ask me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Seeing you again would bring me joy. Yet I advise you to wait a while. Also, to buy a pair of scythes. So you will at least have one sharp blade for reaping.  144 56.

dialogues.speaker: FRANZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: When I look back and think of all the good fortune and graces that have come to us in the seven years since we were married, I see many things that border on being miracles. If someone were to say to me there is no God, or God has no love for us, and, if I were to believe this, I would no longer understand what has happened to me. He has preserved us. He will not abandon us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On her way back to St. Radegund, Fani sees a pretty young woman -- she must be in her late teens -- laughing, caref as Fani herself once was -- innocent, free of suffering.

dialogues.speaker: FANI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (to the children) God knows what we need... want. She remembers a neighbor putting a finger to her lips, shushing her:

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Watch out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The authorities might hear of her protests. She might end as her husband has. What would become of the children? The villagers ostracize her, more from fear than from dis or disapproval. She remembers telling Franz:

dialogues.speaker: FANI
